title: Before 1 December 2017, will it be announced that Wang Qishan has been elected to another term on the Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China?
preds: So, yes, another brier score bites the dust.

@tsm Wow, you are winning big time on this one. Thank you for your many well sourced posts, for example at http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/597677 and your post mortem posted today as a comment at http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/602234.

New politburo standing committee lineup!
No Wang Qishan.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/25/the-seven-men-who-make-up-chinas-new-politburo-xi-jinping

http://www.scmp.com/news/china/policies-politics/article/2116284/hes-anti-graft-tsar-about-leave-chinas-top-leadership
someone who's seen both  lists says Mr. Wang's name is not on them.

yes, seems pretty unlikely. 
http://www.scmp.com/news/china/policies-politics/article/2116411/seasoned-duo-tipped-take-key-jobs-communist-party
age is a moot point when all the rest of them are not able to serve two-terms either.
I think Xi is set staying on past 2022. He has legendary plans. But he still needs to be re-elected. He might be treading carefully for the next five years to secure his long-term position. Keeping Mr. Wang on at this point is quite confrontational if Xi, himself is not sure he has the support to extend his own term.

Wang Qishan, the feared anti-graft tsar billed as “China’s second most powerful man”, is likely to step down from the ruling Communist Party’s supreme Politburo Standing Committee on Wednesday, sources have told the South China Morning Post.

Xi Jinping’s leadership reshuffle revealed: meet the pair poised to become two of China’s most powerful men
Key ally Li Zhanshu in line to become head of National People’s Congress, while Zhao Leji is set to succeed Wang Qishan as anti-corruption tsar
http://m.scmp.com/news/china/policies-politics/article/2116002/xi-jinpings-leadership-reshuffle-begins-meet-pair-about
reading more reports about his opening speech.
Dropping on the back of rumors suggesting he isn't going to serve again.
maybe he could work an informal capacity.

Opening remarks to congress lead me to think he's still a factor
http://www.scmp.com/news/china/policies-politics/article/2115858/key-points-xis-speech-chinas-communist-party-congress

http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/10/china-xi-vows-carry-anti-corruption-crusade-171018045437038.html
To the extent that anti-corruption is a serious priority, keeping Mr. Clean around might be a better idea than it would otherwise be.  Still--coming down a bit, as other commenters make more sense than I do.
was 50/50 on this, but opening remarks and WQ remaining a core player for Xi make me feel the unofficial age rule will not hold back Xi in keeping his man with him.
https://asia.nikkei.com/Spotlight/China-s-party-congress-2017/China-s-anti-graft-czar-Wang-Qishan-to-bow-out-party-sources-say Compensating for lost time with this forecast

Doesn’t look like, apparently only  half of the broader Politburo and 200-strong Central Committee will also change. http://mailchi.mp/eurasiagroup/signal-you-in-power-party-in-beijing-crypto-in-cream
Brilliant analysis by @tsm based upon a data-rich baseline calculation of public appearances by Wnag Qisha at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/594905.

Dateline 10-17-2017 Five of the current seven members of China’s Politburo standing Committee – the highest governing council – are set to retire. Only President Xi, who begins his second five-year term this week, and Prime Minister Li Keqiang will stay on it. About half of the broader Politburo and 200-strong Central Committee will also change. -- http://mailchi.mp/eurasiagroup/signal-you-in-power-party-in-beijing-crypto-in-cream

Xi has effectively sidelined the Politburo by giving himself so many titles. I would expect him to continue his castration of the Politburo and centralisation of power into himself. Just like Trump, Xi has the best possible adviser. Himself. Wang Qishan may continue to have a central role, but it won't be in the Politburo.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-congress-wang/chinas-xi-looks-set-to-keep-right-hand-man-on-despite-age-idUSKBN1CG0JI
"Twelve of the 16 people with ties to China’s leadership, including former officials as well as relatives, aides and close friends of current and former senior officials, said Wang was likely to retain a leadership role. They said it was unclear what Wang’s title would be and whether he would remain on the powerful seven-member Politburo Standing Committee. The other four said he would probably step down."  There seems to be talk of other positions for him whenever he's discussed.

Interesting article on the influence of XI's thought, what appears to be a preference to rule changing instead of rule bending may be in following the first Avoid "Avoid the Soviet Union’s political sclerosis and collapse."

Apparently Wang Qishan will be elected to something on the Politburo, but the Standing Committee might be abolished or morphed into something else. So if this were to come to pass, how would the scorers rule? It seems like at this point we are forecasting the scorers rather than the original question. @amory10, what can you tell us about the scoring situation? Could this question be invalidated if the Standing Committee were to be removed, renamed, morphed? Who does the scoring nowadays when a complication arises?

7th Plenum has begun! Wang is praised and stays, but the system changes. A Chairman system replaces the General Secretary, and the Standing Committee may be no more. Chances? @Xu @tsm @cmeinel @praedico @dsarin others ?
EDIT: I mean ended. The rumors have begun

The fate of the 69-year-old Wang, who keeps a low public profile but is often described as China’s second most powerful politician, has been a source of intense speculation ahead of the Congress, which opens on Oct. 18.

I've jumped the trend to 75% on the idea that as a anti-corruption President Xi will want the services of Wang Q for one more term min. because he cannot be seen as failing to back his hit man. I think the second reason to believe this is that Xi wants to end corruption for another reason that is more self serving...Money from corruption BUILT the power bases for his opposition and it behooves Xi to get the princes under control while nipping opposition in the bud. To leave Wang behind would mean reading someone else in on China's dirty secrets, and introduce the chance of intended or protected targets getting wrapped up in a Corruption investigation.
Here is the forth article about the 19th Party Congress by Andrei Lungu for The Diplomat. He speculates on who will constitute the next Politburo Standing Committee:
Today was Wang's report about his offices' performance ... all stellar.
This is one of those questions that you could probably ask anyone on the street in China, and he would know the answer. But outside of China, forget it.
Thank you, @xu, @tsm for your links to news and your analyses. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/589715

Just a hunch (like all my forecasts on this question): Could it be possible that he will get some kind of new function, important but outside the Standing Committee? He's been quite active lately, outside his usual domain.
Just another article with speculation: https://asia.nikkei.com/Features/Xi-s-power-play/Wang-Qishan-China-s-enforcer-in-chief

Rumours still paint a mixed and contradictory picture, which might be the intention of whoever's leaking: 
"One possible explanation is that Mr Wang, who typically receives international guests such as Mr Bannon accompanied only by an aide or two, will maintain his seat on the Politburo Standing Committee for another five years with a financial and economic portfolio — or even be appointed premier." -
https://www.ft.com/content/c860ac82-9f79-11e7-8cd4-932067fbf946
“There has been speculation that Wang will replace [Premier] Li Keqiang after the party congress, and Beijing will be wanting to avoid stoking those rumours,” Chen said. “But the message is clear about his meeting with Lee – the leadership is behind him on fighting corruption.” - http://www.scmp.com/news/china/policies-politics/article/2112437/secret-meeting-steve-bannon-beijing-adds-speculation
"Wang will step down as secretary of the Central Committee for Discipline Inspection at the Communist Party National Congress in October, sources close to the committee said. He will also likely retire as a Politburo Standing Committee member, according to several Communist Party sources." - http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201709210042.html

Steve Bannon held secret meeting in Beijing
with Wang
https://www.ft.com/content/5cdedd84-9f0c-11e7-8cd4-932067fbf946?
Its the thinking of the hold the power
feel that Xi will try to test the 10-year limit for General Secretary and manoeuvre for a second stint at the highest position.

Xi is making his move but will go relatively slowly during the 19th Party Congress. While he has been steady in accumulating his power, the traditions of the Party and the Constitutional restrictions are serious considerations. Wang Qishan is the indicator of the process. When Xi feels that he is unassailable, Wang's election will happen.
Wang Qishan has reappeared on an Inspection tour of Hunan-王岐山：推动从严治党向基层拓展 回应人民群众的期盼--新闻报道-人民网
He seems far too useful and talented to push into retirement as China struggles with its middle-income trap, domestic demand, etc.

http://nypost.com/2017/08/31/china-adds-rape-allegation-in-case-against-fugitive-billionaire-living-in-new-york/
The Associated Press reviewed documents related to the rape investigation and confirmed their contents with Chinese official sources in Beijing, who requested anonymity to discuss an ongoing case. The Chinese officials’ disclosures to the AP — an unusual move given the political sensitivity of Guo’s case in China — underscores Beijing’s urgent effort to not only bring a fugitive to heel on criminal charges but also silence a potent irritant in the run-up to a key Communist Party congress during which political stability and the stifling of any challenges to the party head, President Xi Jinping, are paramount.

Sources, secrecy, speculation and what's been cited...I think more likely that Xi keeps Wang close, perhaps to open door for 3rd term or because he sees opportunity to advance China's global influence as US is weakened under current admin.
I think he might be either out, or is being tapped for Premier, the Prime minister position. I chose the latter mostly due to a statement picked up by https://sinocism.com/about-2/  and ft.com:

New info - mixed bag of rumours and opinions, though I'm still inclined to believe that he will stay on.
http://www.scmp.com/comment/insight-opinion/article/2105249/what-xi-jinpings-goals-china-say-about-his-focus-personal
http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/graft-buster-wang-qishan-not-on-chinas-new-leadership-line-up-report

Reducing from 65% due to new report. To revisit with more news. http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/graft-buster-wang-qishan-not-on-chinas-new-leadership-line-up-report

Not being mentioned in state media during the whole month of april a good sign of being removed? Excellent podcast btw
listen at 34:00
https://soundcloud.com/user-340830825/cooking-the-news-xis-digital-future
Large chance but would still involve going past the unofficial, long-standing retirement age. Adding uncertainty due to Chinese political volatility.

Based on the articles I read, see below, I think I initially looked too much at the unwritten conventions governing Chinese politics and not enough at the personalities involved. I now think Xi wants allies around him more than he wants to follow conventions and may even want to eliminate the conventions that have governed Chinese politics to this point. After all, blowing up the retirement conventions now may help him change the conventions around retirement in 2023 but that's a forecast for another time.

"This widely regarded Midas touch is one of the reasons why a “Wang-for-premier” campaign has been brewing in Beijing over the past year. Past procedure would suggest that Mr Li will be confirmed in the autumn for another five-year term as premier, while Mr Wang retires. However, in October an official publicly dismissed the supposed retirement age limit as “pure folklore” while a party journal quoted Mr Xi as saying that it “can’t simply draw the line based on age” when appointing officials." - https://www.ft.com/content/d82964ba-6d42-11e7-bfeb-33fe0c5b7eaa
It seems that on balance, Wang is likely to remain on the PSC. But the article also mentions "fierce internal politicking" resulting from his anti-corruption drive which introduces some uncertainty as to whether he will remain on the PSC.
CAN SOMEBODY TELL ME WHAT THIS ARTICLE INDICATE ?
@tsm nice job forecasting this question/thx for the links and analysis along the way.

Wang Qishan, Xi's close friend and member of the Politburo Standing Committee, accused of corruption, it is looking more likely that the congress will be held at the usual time.
http://asia.nikkei.com/Politics-Economy/Policy-Politics/Xi-promotes-loyalists-from-bottom-of-Communist-Party-pyramid

The position held by Wang Qishan has changed officials in November every 5 years except once in the past four decades.  The current cycle should be complete this November and his position of Secretary of the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection deals with economic issues.  The only person to have 2 five year terms in the past four decades held the position during the 90's when China's economy was skyrocketing.  There are currently enough economic issues for China to rotate Wang Qishan out of his position.
Where is the evidence that he is going to stay?

Mr Wang appeared in a nationwide teleconference earier this week: Whopping 120,000 disciplinary inspectors watched the broadcast!
http://www.ecns.cn/2017/07-04/263866.shtml

- Wang Qishan is using anti-corruption platform and resources to stop corruption, stop and obstruct corrupt officials, to obstruct cronies, to obstruct political opponents. 
-Very savvy guy (means he works sort like the kings/queens of Europe; outmanoeuvring opponents using various strategies including marrying into lineage.)
- Xi can make a case for overturning age limit. I think motion would pass in China where age is revered.
- also Xi is popular and has done very well for China ito economy and increasing standard of living
- Quishan has strong, deep ties to previous and former Chinese rulers  - 'a princeling'
- Q has successfully and without a lot of vocal opposition, incarcerated several Chinese businessmen and state officials with ties and resources outside of China
- support of US republican administration in past, assume current admin might have a sort of favourable mein

[2017/06/26] Li Keqian now is the formal successor, but President Xi would like to replace him with Wang Qishan. While Wang Qishan is over 68 when it is 2018, the internal rule of communist party is above or equal to 68 years leave, below 68 stay. I think Xi needs some political  wrist to change this.
Despite Xi's influence, the electors aren't going to want to disrupt the status quo, particularly if it could set a precedent with Xi's own re-election chances

Revised estimate based on status as generational cohort 4.5 and age retirement requirements (informally observed since 2002).  Despite his current standing in the politburo it is possible that he might be appointed at the 19th Congress.  He has however expressed retirement following current norms among generational cohorts within the leadership.
王岐山 was born on July 1, 1948 (age 68).[1]

I'm going to buck the consensus here simply because Mr. Wang will be over the official retirement age of 68 set in 16th party congress in 2002. As well, as per the article below, he has been working to fortify the CCDI (the anti corruption unit he runs) to make sure it keeps functioning as it has once he's gone.
The status quo works well for China currently.

oops. this will cost me.
[edit: 10/24: should've stuck with this forecast...]

Intriligator has placed significant emphasis on anti corruption within CCP and society, Qishan (has chaired the Disciplinary Committee within the politburo) maintains popular support by media in China and the ruling party and its propaganda organs.  Many within the Poliburo are eager to see him retains membership within the politburo.  The 19th Congress occurring this year, we will see reelection.  He is considered to be the second most powerful leader within the CCP.
If Wang's election is a test of Xi's power then I think it will happen.

He is, I think, past the unofficial retirement age or soon will be.  On the other hand he has been a BFF of Xi's, assisting in various efforts important to The Big Kahuna, especially anticorruption and other forms of laxity among the faithful.   Odds are in his favour, but yet overwhelmingly.  Stay tuned.
